title: Contributing Guidelines
text: manuscript files built using dynamic documentation tool knitr .Rmd versions file. Please edit .md versions since files built automatically. .md versions built viewing Github, take advantage Github’s rendering display text-based diffs. .md files generated using Makefile provided, also handle details Github-compatible syntax highlighting embedding images. Makefile also generate pdf version manuscript using pandoc appropriate LaTeX templates. Text hard-wrapped less 80 characters width possible. allows git better track real changes files impoves display line-based diffs. reason, also avoid re-wrapping text frequently, changing line end encodings, etc. Embedding images: Image generation handled markdown file, embed online png images published imgur .md output, vector pdf graphics .pdf manuscript. Citations: Citations added .Rmd file using pandoc markdown notation, corresponding bibtex entries added citations.bib. Citations can also added standard markdown link. Caching avoid rerunning potentially slow R code embedded mansucript simply view changes text, results running code cached cache (see knitr documentation details caching used). Run make clean erase cache clear workspace. Recall Makefile rerun relevant command source file changed. Consequently, changes package functions automatically cause make recompile manuscript.

title: The nexml S4 Object
text: RNeXML package provides many convenient functions add extract information nexml objects R environment without requiring reader understand details NeXML data structure making less likely user generate invalid NeXML syntax read parsers. nexml object using examples built R’s S4 mechanism. Advanced users may sometimes prefer interact data structure directly using R’s S4 class mechanism subsetting methods. Many R users familiar S3 class mechanism (ape package phylo objects) rather S4 class mechanism used phylogenetics packages ouch phylobase. phylobase vignette provides excellent introduction data structures. Users already familiar subsetting lists S3 objects R likely familiar use $ operator, phy$edge. S4 objects simply use @ operator instead (subset using numeric arguments phy[[1]] named arguments phy[[“edge”]]). nexml object S4 object, components (slots). hierarchical structure corresponds exactly XML tree NeXML file, single exception XML attributes children represented slots. S4 objects constructor functions initialize . create new nexml object command: can see list slots contained object slots already populated us, instance, schema version default namespaces: Recognize nex@namespaces serves role get_namespaces function, provides direct access slot data. instance, syntax also overwrite existing namespaces nex@namespaces <- NULL. Changing namespace way advised. slots can contain multiple elements type, trees, characters, otus. instance, see object class ListOfcharacters, currently empty, order assign object slot, must match class definition slot. can create new element given class new function, now length-1 list character matrices, access first character matrix using list notation, [[1]]. check class characters object. Direct subsetting two primary use cases: () useful looking (possibly editing) specific value element, (b) adding metadata annotations specific elements. Consider example file can look species label first otu first otus block: can add metadata particular OTU using subsetting format use c operator append element existing meta annotations otu.
code: nex <- new("nexml") slotNames(nex) [1] "version"            "generator"          "xsi:schemaLocation" "namespaces"         "otus"                [6] "trees"              "characters"         "meta"               "about"              "xsi:type" nex@version [1] "0.9" nex@namespaces nex                                              xsi                       "http://www.nexml.org/2009"      "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"                                               xml                                             cdao            "http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace"                "http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/"                                               xsd                                               dc               "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#"               "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"                                           dcterms                                            prism                       "http://purl.org/dc/terms/" "http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/"                                                cc                                             ncbi                  "http://creativecommons.org/ns#"          "http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy#"                                                tc                                                    "http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#"                      "http://www.nexml.org/2009" class(nex@characters) [1] "ListOfcharacters" attr(,"package") [1] "RNeXML" length(nex@characters) [1] 0 nex@characters <- new("ListOfcharacters", list(new("characters"))) length(nex@characters) [1] 1 class(nex@characters[[1]]) [1] "characters" attr(,"package") [1] "RNeXML" f <- system.file("examples", "trees.xml", package="RNeXML") nex <- nexml_read(f) nex@otus[[1]]@otu[[1]]@label label  "species 1" nex@otus[[1]]@otu[[1]]@meta <-    c(meta("skos:note",            "This species was incorrectly identified"),          nex@otus[[1]]@otu[[1]]@meta)

title: A Brief Introduction to RNeXML
text: can also add arbitrary metadata NeXML tree define meta objects: Advanced use requires specifying namespace used. Metadata follows RDFa conventions. indicate modification date using prism vocabulary. namespace included default, used basic metadata shown previous example. can see list: next block defines resource (link), described rel attribute homepage, term foaf vocabulary. foaf default namespace, provide URL full definition . create history node using skos namespace. can also add id values metadata element make element easier reference externally: kind richer annotation, best build NeXML object sequentially. First add bird.orders phylogeny new phylogenetic object, add metadata elements created object. Finally, write object XML file:
code: modified <- meta(property = "prism:modificationDate",                  content = "2013-10-04") RNeXML:::nexml_namespaces ##                                              nex                                              xsi  ##                      "http://www.nexml.org/2009"      "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"  ##                                              xml                                             cdao  ##           "http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace"                "http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/"  ##                                              xsd                                               dc  ##              "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#"               "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  ##                                          dcterms                                            prism  ##                      "http://purl.org/dc/terms/" "http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/"  ##                                               cc                                             ncbi  ##                 "http://creativecommons.org/ns#"          "http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy#"  ##                                               tc  ##  "http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#" website <- meta(href = "http://carlboettiger.info",                  rel = "foaf:homepage") history <- meta(property = "skos:historyNote",                    content = "Mapped from the bird.orders data in the ape package using RNeXML",                   id = "meta123") birds <- add_trees(bird.orders)   birds <- add_meta(meta = list(history, modified, website),                     namespaces = c(skos = "http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#",                                    foaf = "http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/"),                     nexml=birds)   nexml_write(birds,                file = "example.xml") ## [1] "example.xml"

title: A Brief Introduction to RNeXML
text: can load library, parse NeXML file extract characters phylogeny. (Note get_characters return discrete continuous characters together data.frame, use get_characters_list get separate data.frames continuous characters block discrete characters block). can fire geiger fit, say, Brownian motion model continuous data Markov transition matrix discrete states:
code: library(RNeXML) nexml <- read.nexml(system.file("examples", "comp_analysis.xml", package="RNeXML")) traits <- get_characters(nexml) tree <- get_trees(nexml) library(geiger) fitContinuous(tree, traits[1], ncores=1) fitDiscrete(tree, traits[2], ncores=1)

title: Handling Metadata in RNeXML
text: add_basic_meta() function takes input existing nexml object (like add_ functions, none provided create one), time writing following parameters: title, description, creator, pubdate, rights, publisher, citation. metadata elements corresponding parameters may added future. Load packages data: Create nexml object phylogeny bird.orders add appropriate metadata: Instead literal string, citations can also provided R’s bibentry type, one R package citations obtained:
code: library('RNeXML') data(bird.orders) birds <- add_trees(bird.orders) birds <- add_basic_meta(   title = "Phylogeny of the Orders of Birds From Sibley and Ahlquist",    description = "This data set describes the phylogenetic relationships of the      orders of birds as reported by Sibley and Ahlquist (1990). Sibley      and Ahlquist inferred this phylogeny from an extensive number of      DNA/DNA hybridization experiments. The ``tapestry'' reported by      these two authors (more than 1000 species out of the ca. 9000      extant bird species) generated a lot of debates.       The present tree is based on the relationships among orders. The      branch lengths were calculated from the values of Delta T50H as      found in Sibley and Ahlquist (1990, fig. 353).",    citation = "Sibley, C. G. and Ahlquist, J. E. (1990) Phylogeny and      classification of birds: a study in molecular evolution. New      Haven: Yale University Press.",    creator = "Sibley, C. G. and Ahlquist, J. E.",     nexml=birds) birds <- add_basic_meta(citation = citation("ape"), nexml = birds)

RNeXML package can easily extended support helper functions taxize_nexml add additional metadata without imposing large burden user.
code: prefixes <- get_namespaces(birds) prefixes["dc"] dc  "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" modified <- meta(property = "prism:modificationDate", content = "2013-10-04") birds <- add_meta(modified, birds) history <- meta(property = "skos:historyNote",   content = "Mapped from the bird.orders data in the ape package using RNeXML") birds <- add_meta(history,                  birds,                  level = "trees",                 namespaces = c(skos = "http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#"))

title: Extending NeXML: an example based on simmap

Revell (2012) describes phytools package R, includes utilities reading, manipulating, writing simmap files R. example, also show define RNeXML functions map R representation used Revell (extension ape class) NeXML extension defined using RNeXML functions. Since stochastic character map simply assigns different states parts branch (edge) phylogenetic tree, can create NeXML representation annotating edge elements appropriate meta elements. elements need describe character state assigned duration (terms branch-length) edge spends state (Stochastic character maps specific time-calibrated ultrametric trees). RNeXML automatically detects simmap reconstruction data returns includes maps element ape::phylo object, use phytools functions. can use various functions phytools designed simmap objects (Revell 2012), plotting function: Stochastic character mapping phylogeny, generated phytools package parsing simmap-extended NeXML. title: SPARQL with RNeXML
text: Rich, semantically meaningful metadata lies heart NeXML standard. (example looks complex, try writing steps without aid SPARQL queries). examples show manipulation semantic triples, Unique Resource Identifiers (URIs) use SPARQL “Join” operator. Note example can run using demo("sparql", "RNeXML") see code displayed R terminal avoid character errors can occur copy paste PDF files. begin extracting RDF graph NeXML, fetch NCBI URI taxon rank ‘Order’, .e. root primates phylogeny. dot operator . clauses implies join, case makes use SPARQL query language provided rrdf package. also define helper functions use SPARQL queries. define function get name Next, define recursive function build newick tree taxonomic rank information. functions place, straight forward build tree semantic RDFa data visualize plot chunk unnamed-chunk-8
code: library("rdflib") library("xml2") library("phytools") library("RNeXML") nexml <- nexml_read(system.file("examples/primates.xml", package="RNeXML")) <otu about="#ou541" id="ou541" label="Alouatta guariba">       <meta href="http://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy/182256"              id="ma20"              rel="concept:toTaxon"              xsi:type="nex:ResourceMeta"/>       <meta href="http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonRank#Species"              id="ma21"              rel="concept:rank"              xsi:type="nex:ResourceMeta"/>       <meta href="http://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy/9499"              id="ma22"              rel="rdfs:subClassOf"              xsi:type="nex:ResourceMeta"/>     </otu> rdf <- get_rdf(system.file("examples/primates.xml", package="RNeXML")) tmp <- tempfile()  # so we must write the XML out first xml2::write_xml(rdf, tmp)   graph <- rdf_parse(tmp) root <- rdf_query(graph,  "SELECT ?uri WHERE {      ?id <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#rank> <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonRank#Order> .      ?id <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#toTaxon> ?uri     }") get_name <- function(id) {   max <- length(nexml@otus[[1]]@otu)   for(i in 1:max) {     if ( nexml@otus[[1]]@otu[[i]]@id == id ) {       label <- nexml@otus[[1]]@otu[[i]]@label       label <- gsub(" ","_",label)       return(label)     }   } } recurse <- function(node){        # fetch the taxonomic rank and id string     rank_query <- paste0(         "SELECT ?rank ?id WHERE {             ?id <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#toTaxon> <",node,"> .             ?id <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#rank> ?rank           }")     result <- rdf_query(graph, rank_query)          # get the local ID, strip URI part     id <- result$id     id <- gsub("^.+#", "", id, perl = TRUE)          # if rank is terminal, return the name     if (result$rank == "http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonRank#Species") {         return(get_name(id))     }          # recurse deeper     else {         child_query <- paste0(             "SELECT ?uri WHERE {                 ?id <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#subClassOf> <",node,"> .                 ?id <http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/TaxonConcept#toTaxon> ?uri             }")         children <- rdf_query(graph, child_query)                  return(paste("(",                       paste(sapply(children$uri, recurse),                             sep = ",", collapse = "," ),                       ")",                        get_name(id), # label interior nodes                      sep = "", collapse = ""))     } } newick <- paste(recurse(root), ";", sep = "", collapse = "") tree <- read.newick(text = newick) collapsed <- collapse.singles(tree) plot(collapsed,       type='cladogram',       show.tip.label=FALSE,       show.node.label=TRUE,       cex=0.75,       edge.color='grey60',       label.offset=-9)

code: ## Create a new nexml object with a single metadata element:  modified <- meta(property = "prism:modificationDate", content = "2013-10-04") nex <- add_meta(modified) # Note: 'prism' is defined in nexml_namespaces by default.    ## Write multiple metadata elements, including a new namespace:   website <- meta(href = "http://carlboettiger.info",                  rel = "foaf:homepage")              # meta can be link-style metadata nex <- add_meta(list(modified,  website),                  namespaces = c(foaf = "http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/"))  ## Append more metadata, and specify a level:  history <- meta(property = "skos:historyNote",                  content = "Mapped from the bird.orders data in the ape package using RNeXML") data(bird.orders) nex <- add_trees(bird.orders) # need to have created a trees block first nex <- add_meta(history,                  nexml = nex,                 level = "trees",                 namespaces = c(skos = "http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#"))

code: uris <- c("cc:license", "dc:title") ns <- c(dc = "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/",         dcterms = "http://purl.org/dc/terms/",         dct = "http://purl.org/dc/terms/",         cc = "http://creativecommons.org/ns#") # expansion is vectorized expand_prefix(uris, ns) #> [1] "http://creativecommons.org/ns#license" #> [2] "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title"  # strings with non-matching or no prefix are left as is uris <- c(uris, "my:title", "title") expand_prefix(uris, ns) #> [1] "http://creativecommons.org/ns#license" #> [2] "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title" #> [3] "my:title"                              #> [4] "title"                                  # NAs in the input list become NA in the output uris <- c(uris, NA) expand_prefix(uris, ns) #> [1] "http://creativecommons.org/ns#license" #> [2] "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title" #> [3] "my:title"                              #> [4] "title"                                 #> [5] NA                                       # can include a "base" (unnamed) namespace for expanding unprefixed strings ns <- c(ns, "//local/") xuris <- expand_prefix(uris, ns) xuris #> [1] "http://creativecommons.org/ns#license" #> [2] "http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title" #> [3] "my:title"                              #> [4] "//local/title"                         #> [5] NA                                      xuris[uris == "title"] == paste0("//local/", uris[uris == "title"]) #> [1] TRUE   NA  # different prefixes may expand to the same result expand_prefix("dcterms:modified", ns) == expand_prefix("dct:modified", ns) #> [1] TRUE  # or they may result in different expansions expand_prefix("dc:title", ns) != expand_prefix("dcterms:title", ns) #> [1] TRUE

title: Get character data.frame from nexml — get_characters
text: RNeXML attempt return matrix using NeXML taxon (otu) labels name rows NeXML char labels name traits (columns).  unavailable unique, NeXML id values otus traits used instead.

title: Get character data.frame from nexml — get_characters
code: if (FALSE) { # A simple example with a discrete and a continous trait f <- system.file("examples", "comp_analysis.xml", package="RNeXML") nex <- read.nexml(f) get_characters(nex)  # A more complex example -- currently ignores sequence-type characters f <- system.file("examples", "characters.xml", package="RNeXML") nex <- read.nexml(f) get_characters(nex)  # if polymorphic or uncertain states need special treatment, request state # types to be returned as well: f <- system.file("examples", "ontotrace-result.xml", package="RNeXML") nex <- read.nexml(f) res <- get_characters(nex, include_state_types = TRUE) row.has.p <- apply(res$state_types, 1,                     function(x) any(x == "polymorphic", na.rm = TRUE)) col.has.p <- apply(res$state_types, 2,                     function(x) any(x == "polymorphic", na.rm = TRUE)) res$characters[row.has.p, col.has.p, drop=FALSE] # polymorphic rows and cols res$characters[!row.has.p, drop=FALSE] # drop taxa with polymorphic states # replace polymorphic state symbols in matrix with '?' m1 <- mapply(function(s, s.t) ifelse(s.t == "standard", s, "?"),               res$characters, res$state_types) row.names(m1) <- row.names(res$characters) m1 }

title: get_level — get_level
text: level character vector giving path specified node group.  instance, otus, characters, trees top-level blocks (e.g. child nodes root nexml block), can specified directly.  get metadata "char" elements characters blocks, must specify char nodes child nodes character nodes: e.g. get_level(nex, "characters/char"), similarly states: get_level(nex, characters/states). return object data frame whose columns attribute names elements specified. column names match attribute names except "id" attribute, column renamed using node . (Thus <otus id="os2"> rendered data.frame column called "otus" instead "id"). Additional columns added parent element path; e.g. get_level(nex, "otus/otu") include column named "otus" id otus block.  Even though method always returns data frame matching nodes blocks, ids let see otu values came otus block.  identical function call get_taxa(). Similarly, get_level(nex, "otus/otu/meta") return additional columns 'otus' also column, 'otu', otu parent ids metadata block.  (identical function call get_metadata).  makes easier join data.frames well, see examples

title: Get the desired element from the nexml object — nexml_get
text: return type depends element requested.  See details.

title: Get the desired element from the nexml object — nexml_get
text: "tree" ape::phylo tree, one tree represented.  Otherwise returns list lists multiphylo trees.  consistently receive list lists format (preserving hierarchical nature nexml), use trees instead. "trees" returns list lists multiphylo trees, even trees trees node (hence outer list length 1) single tree (hence inner list also length 1.  ensures consistent return type regardless number trees present nexml file, also preserves hierarchy/grouping trees. "flat_trees" multiPhylo object (list ape::phylo objects) Note method collapses hierarchical structure may present multiple trees nodes original nexml (though feature rarely used).  preserve structure, use trees instead. "metadata"Get metadata specified level (default top/nexml level) "otu" returns named character vector containing available metadata.  names indicate property (rel case links/resourceMeta), values indicate content (href links). "taxa" alias otu slightly cleaner interface, elements also defined S4 method nexml object.  place get_item(nexml, "tree"), one use get_tree(nexml), forth element type.

title: Get the desired element from the nexml object — nexml_get
code: comp_analysis <- system.file("examples", "comp_analysis.xml", package="RNeXML") nex <- nexml_read(comp_analysis) nexml_get(nex, "trees") #>  #> Phylogenetic tree with 10 tips and 9 internal nodes. #>  #> Tip labels: #>   taxon_8, taxon_9, taxon_10, taxon_1, taxon_2, taxon_3, ... #>  #> Rooted; includes branch lengths. nexml_get(nex, "characters_list") #> $cs15 #>            NA log snout-vent length #> taxon_8  ou10            -3.2777799 #> taxon_9  ou11             2.0959433 #> taxon_10 ou12             3.1373971 #> taxon_1   ou3             4.7532824 #> taxon_2   ou4            -2.7624146 #> taxon_3   ou5             2.1049413 #> taxon_4   ou6            -4.9504770 #> taxon_5   ou7             1.2714718 #> taxon_6   ou8             6.2593966 #> taxon_7   ou9             0.9099634 #>  #> $cs31 #>          reef-dwelling #> taxon_8              0 #> taxon_9              1 #> taxon_10             0 #> taxon_1              1 #> taxon_2              0 #> taxon_3              0 #> taxon_4              0 #> taxon_5              1 #> taxon_6              1 #> taxon_7              1 #>

code: nex <- nexml_read(system.file("examples", "comp_analysis.xml", package = "RNeXML")) s <- summary(nex) # number of major blocks: s$nblocks #>      trees       otus characters  #>          1          1          2   # each characters block defines 1 character: s$ncharacters #> block.1 block.2  #>       1       1   # summary stats of states per character (for morphological matrices there is # typically one state set per character) s$nstates # note that first block is of continuous type, so no stats there #>         block.1 block.2 #> Min.         NA       2 #> 1st Qu.      NA       2 #> Median       NA       2 #> Mean         NA       2 #> 3rd Qu.      NA       2 #> Max.         NA       2  # pretty-printed summary: nex # this is the same as show(nex) #> A nexml object representing: #>  	 1 phylogenetic tree block(s), where: #> 	   block 1 contains 1 phylogenetic tree(s)  #>  	 2 character block(s), where: #> 	   block 1 defines 1 continuous character(s)  #> 	   matrix 1 has 10 row(s) #> 	   block 2 defines 1 standard/discrete character(s), with 2 states each  #> 	    and  0 polymorphic or uncertain state(s) defined  #> 	   matrix 2 has 10 row(s)  #>  	 10 taxonomic units in 1 block(s)  #>   Taxa:	 taxon_1, taxon_2, taxon_3, taxon_4, taxon_5, taxon_6 ... #>   Metadata annotations:  #> 	2 at top level  #> 	0 in block 1 at otu level  #> 	0 in block 1 at char level #> 	0 in block 2 at char level  #> 	0 in block 1 at state level #> 	0 in block 2 at state level #>  #> Author(s): rvosa #>  #> NeXML generated by Bio::Phylo::Project v.0.56 using schema version: 0.9  #> Size: 289.3 Kb
